items.content: Davie's exit caps week of attacks on UK's public broadcaster, with Trump press secretary calling it '100% fake news'.

items.title: Why has Tim Davie resigned and what was the Trump documentary edit?
items.standfirst: The BBC has come under fire over a Panorama documentary that was accused of misleadingly editing a speech by Donald Trump.
items.content: The BBC has come under fire over a Panorama documentary that was accused of misleadingly editing a speech by Donald Trump.

items.title: ‘I have to take ultimate responsibility’: Tim Davie’s BBC resignation statement
items.standfirst: Full text of director general’s note to staff and the resignation statement from head of news Deborah TurnessDavie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverageBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.This afternoon Davie sent the following note to staff:Dear all,I wanted to let you know that I have decided to leave the BBC after 20 years. This is entirely my decision, and I remain very thankful to the Chair and Board for their unswerving and unanimous support throughout my entire tenure, including during recent days.Dear all,I have never been more proud of the work that you do every day. You really are the best of the best. Continue reading...
items.content: Full text of director general’s note to staff and the resignation statement from head of news Deborah TurnessDavie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverageBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.This afternoon Davie sent the following note to staff:Dear all,I wanted to let you know that I have decided to leave the BBC after 20 years. This is entirely my decision, and I remain very thankful to the Chair and Board for their unswerving and unanimous support throughout my entire tenure, including during recent days.Dear all,I have never been more proud of the work that you do every day. You really are the best of the best. Continue reading...

items.title: Tim Davie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverage
items.standfirst: Davie says departure is ‘my own decision’, while head of news also quits. Insiders say it ‘feels like a coup’ by broadcaster’s enemiesBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.In an announcement that caused shock within the corporation, Davie said his departure was “entirely my decision” and it comes as the BBC prepares to apologise for the way it edited a Trump speech. Continue reading...
items.content: Davie says departure is ‘my own decision’, while head of news also quits. Insiders say it ‘feels like a coup’ by broadcaster’s enemiesBBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignationsTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.In an announcement that caused shock within the corporation, Davie said his departure was “entirely my decision” and it comes as the BBC prepares to apologise for the way it edited a Trump speech. Continue reading...

items.title: BBC director resigns after row over Trump documentary edit
items.standfirst: The director general of Britain's BBC, Tim Davie, and the chief executive of news, Deborah Turness, have stepped down following criticism over bias at the corporation, including in the way it edited a speech by US President Donald Trump.
items.content: The director general of Britain's BBC, Tim Davie, and the chief executive of news, Deborah Turness, have stepped down following criticism over bias at the corporation, including in the way it edited a speech by US President Donald Trump.

items.title: BBC director resigns after criticism of the broadcaster's editing of a Trump speech
items.standfirst: The BBC said that director-general Tim Davie and head of news Deborah Turness have resigned after criticism of the broadcaster's editing of a speech by U.S. President Donald Trump.
items.content: The BBC said that director-general Tim Davie and head of news Deborah Turness have resigned after criticism of the broadcaster's editing of a speech by U.S. President Donald Trump.(Image credit: Hannah McKay)

ai_summary: BBC Director General Tim Davie resigned following criticism of a Trump documentary edit.
News CEO Deborah Turness also resigned due to the same controversy.
The resignations followed backlash over the editing of a Trump speech.
The documentary edit was accused of misleading viewers by critics.
Donald Trump thanked the Telegraph for exposing "corrupt journalists" at the BBC.

clusters.title: Two dead, one million evacuated as Typhoon Fung-wong slams into the Philippines
clusters.neutral_headline: Typhoon Fung-wong Hits Philippines, Causing Evacuations

items.title: Two dead, one million evacuated as Typhoon Fung-wong slams into the Philippines
Philippines hit by 'intense' typhoon as nearly a million evacuate
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong, with sustained winds of 185 km/h (115mph), hit the Philippines as a super typhoon and later weakened.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong, with sustained winds of 185 km/h (115mph), hit the Philippines as a super typhoon and later weakened.

items.title: More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall
items.standfirst: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...
items.content: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...

items.title: BBC on Luzon Island as super typhoon hits Philippines
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.

items.title: Nearly one million evacuated as Typhoon Fung-wong nears Philippines
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong is approaching the Philippines, forcing nearly a million people to evacuate.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong is approaching the Philippines, forcing nearly a million people to evacuate.

items.title: Nearly a million people evacuate as Super Typhoon Fung-wong threatens the Philippines
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong, the biggest storm to threaten the Philippines this year, started battering the country's northeastern coast ahead of landfall on Sunday.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong, the biggest storm to threaten the Philippines this year, started battering the country's northeastern coast ahead of landfall on Sunday.(Image credit: Malacanang Presidential Communications Office)

items.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong hits Philippines - with two dead and one million people evacuated
items.standfirst: Two people have died and more than one million people evacuated after a storm bearing down on the Philippines intensified into a super typhoon and made landfall on Sunday.
items.content: Two people have died and more than one million people evacuated after a storm bearing down on the Philippines intensified into a super typhoon and made landfall on Sunday.

ai_summary: Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall in the Philippines with strong winds.
Over one million people were evacuated due to the approaching storm.
At least two deaths were reported as a result of the typhoon.
The typhoon was the second major storm to hit the Philippines recently.
The storm crossed over Luzon, the most populous island in the Philippines.

items.title: Senate advances funding measure, moving a step closer to ending shutdown
items.standfirst: On Day 40 of the shutdown, eight Democrats joined Republicans in advancing a government funding measure, after 14 previous votes fell short.
items.content: On Day 40 of the shutdown, eight Democrats joined Republicans in advancing a government funding measure, after 14 previous votes fell short.

items.content: In a bid to end a historic government shutdown, the Senate begins a procedural vote on a deal. MSNBC's Kevin Frey reports the ...

items.title: US Senate vote marks step towards ending federal shutdown
items.standfirst: Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reachThe US Senate on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded.Senators began voting on Sunday night to advance House-passed stopgap funding legislation that Senate majority leader John Thune said would be amended to combine another short-term spending measure with a package of three full-year appropriations bills. Continue reading...
items.content: Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reachThe US Senate on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded.Senators began voting on Sunday night to advance House-passed stopgap funding legislation that Senate majority leader John Thune said would be amended to combine another short-term spending measure with a package of three full-year appropriations bills. Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: Thune says he's hopeful government shutdown will end ahead of vote on key funding bill
items.standfirst: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said he was "hopeful that we can finally bring the shutdown to an end" ahead of a vote to advance a key funding bill. At least eight Democrats said they would back the deal.
items.content: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said he was "hopeful that we can finally bring the shutdown to an end" ahead of a vote to advance a key funding bill. At least eight Democrats said they would back the deal.

items.title: Senate Democrats blink on the shutdown after 40 days of pain

items.content: After nearly six weeks of a painful shutdown, a critical number of Senate Democrats are backing a Republican funding bill to reopen government — with little to show for holding out so long

items.content: The Senate is poised to take a procedural vote on a deal negotiated between rank-and-file members that will likely have sufficient Democratic support to overcome the 60 vote filibuster, sources tell MSNBC.

items.content: Sens. Bernie Sanders and Chuck Schumer spoke out against a funding deal that has the support of at least eight Democrats, which could end the government shutdown. Both senators emphasized the health care fight and rising costs for Americans.

items.standfirst: Syria Puts On Show Of 'Major ISIS Crackdown' As Sharaa Arrives In D.C. For Trump Talks Via The Cradle Self-appointed Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa arrived in Washington on Sunday, following the completion of what Syrian security officials claimed was a large security operation targeting ISIS…

For Trump Talks Via The Cradle Self-appointed Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa arrived in Washington on Sunday, following the completion of what Syrian security officials claimed was a large security operation targeting ISIS…

items.title: Syrian president al-Sharaa arrives in US for landmark White House visit
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US on Ssturday where he is due to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House – the first such visit by a Syrian president since the country's independence in 1946. Ahead of al-Sharaa's visit the leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist. Shirli Sitbon has this story.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US on Ssturday where he is due to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House – the first such visit by a Syrian president since the country's independence in 1946. Ahead of al-Sharaa's visit the leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist. Shirli Sitbon has this story.

items.title: Syria's Sharaa arrives in US for Trump talks after sanctions lifted
items.standfirst: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.
items.content: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.

items.title: Explosives and weapons seized - with 71 arrests - as Syria launches clampdown on Islamic State cells
items.standfirst: Syria has carried out pre-emptive operations targeting Islamic State cells - arresting 71 people during 61 raids.
items.content: Syria has carried out pre-emptive operations targeting Islamic State cells - arresting 71 people during 61 raids.

items.title: Syria carries out preemptive raids against Islamic State
items.standfirst: Security operations came as Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in Washington to meet Donald TrumpSyria has carried out nationwide preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells, a spokesperson for the interior ministry said on Saturday, as the country’s president arrived in the US for talks with Donald Trump.Syrian security forces carried out 61 raids, with 71 people arrested and explosives and weapons seized, the spokesperson told state-run Al Ekhbariya TV. Continue reading...
items.content: Security operations came as Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in Washington to meet Donald TrumpSyria has carried out nationwide preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells, a spokesperson for the interior ministry said on Saturday, as the country’s president arrived in the US for talks with Donald Trump.Syrian security forces carried out 61 raids, with 71 people arrested and explosives and weapons seized, the spokesperson told state-run Al Ekhbariya TV. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa arrived in Washington for talks with Trump.
Syria claimed to have launched a major crackdown on ISIS cells.
The visit was the first by a Syrian president since the 1940s.
71 people were arrested in preemptive raids against ISIS cells.
Explosives and weapons were seized during the security operations.

items.standfirst: Two Major League Baseball pitchers have been indicted on charges they took bribes to give bettors advance notice of the types of pitches they'd throw and intentionally tossed balls instead of strikes.
items.content: Two Major League Baseball pitchers have been indicted on charges they took bribes to give bettors advance notice of the types of pitches they'd throw and intentionally tossed balls instead of strikes.(Image credit: Sue Ogrocki)

items.title: MLB pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz charged with taking bribes to rig pitches for bettors

ai_summary: MLB pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz were charged with taking bribes.
They are accused of rigging pitches for bettors in exchange for money.
Federal agents arrested Luis Leandro Ortiz Ribera in Boston.
The charges involve giving bettors advance notice of pitch types.
The pitchers allegedly intentionally threw balls instead of strikes.

items.title: Israel receives body of soldier killed in 2014 in Gaza
items.standfirst: The Israeli military confirmed the soldier's body had been returned from Gaza after 11 years on Sunday.
items.content: The Israeli military confirmed the soldier's body had been returned from Gaza after 11 years on Sunday.

items.title: Israel receives remains of soldier killed in Gaza in 2014
items.standfirst: Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.
items.content: Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.

items.title: Israel receives remains of hostage that Hamas says is IDF soldier killed in 2014
items.standfirst: Hadar Goldin was killed on Aug. 1, 2014, two hours after a ceasefire took effect ending that year's war between Israel and Hamas.
items.content: Hadar Goldin was killed on Aug. 1, 2014, two hours after a ceasefire took effect ending that year's war between Israel and Hamas.(Image credit: Mahmoud Illean)

items.title: Israel receives the remains of a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014
items.standfirst: Israel on Sunday confirmed it had received the remains of Hadar Goldin, a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014. The return of Goldin's remains marked the end of an 11-year effort by his family and closed a painful chapter in the country’s long conflict with Hamas.
items.content: Israel on Sunday confirmed it had received the remains of Hadar Goldin, a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014. The return of Goldin's remains marked the end of an 11-year effort by his family and closed a painful chapter in the country’s long conflict with Hamas.

ai_summary: Israel received the remains of a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014.
The soldier was identified as Hadar Goldin.
The remains were returned after an 11-year effort.
Hamas claims the remains are of an IDF soldier.
The return of the remains closed a painful chapter.

clusters.title: US senators reach deal aimed at ending longest government shutdown in history
clusters.neutral_headline: Government Shutdown Causes Flight Disruptions

items.title: US senators reach deal aimed at ending longest government shutdown in history
items.standfirst: US senators struck a bipartisan deal Sunday to restore federal funding and end a record 40-day government shutdown that crippled operations nationwide. The agreement, a preliminary step toward reopening, came as authorities warned air travel could “slow to a trickle” amid thousands of weekend flight cancellations and delays.
items.content: US senators struck a bipartisan deal Sunday to restore federal funding and end a record 40-day government shutdown that crippled operations nationwide. The agreement, a preliminary step toward reopening, came as authorities warned air travel could “slow to a trickle” amid thousands of weekend flight cancellations and delays.

items.title: Government shutdown cancels 400 O’Hare flights, delays 1,000 ahead of snowstorm and more disruptions
items.standfirst: As a Federal Aviation Administration emergency order to cut flights because of the government shutdown entered its third day on Sunday, travel was further disrupted at O’Hare International Airport, with over 400 flight cancellations and over 1,150 delays as of the early evening. The cancellations…

items.title: US Government shutdown hits 39th day
items.standfirst: Over 1,400 US flights were canceled Saturday after airlines cut traffic due to the federal government shutdown. Nearly 6,000 more were delayed, down from 7,000 on Friday, FlightAware reports. The FAA is reducing capacity at 40 busy airports as unpaid, fatigued air traffic controllers work. Lawmakers remain deadlocked over ending the shutdown, now in its second week. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson reports the latest.
items.content: Over 1,400 US flights were canceled Saturday after airlines cut traffic due to the federal government shutdown. Lawmakers remain deadlocked over ending the shutdown, now in its second week. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson reports the latest.

items.title: Trump booed at Commanders NFL game before calling plays from Fox broadcast booth
items.standfirst: President greeted with jeers by many fans at gameTrump has appeared at several sports events this yearDonald Trump became the first sitting US president in nearly 50 years to attend a regular-season NFL game when he dropped in on the Detroit Lions’ win over the Washington Commanders on Sunday.There were boos from large sections of fans, as well as scattered cheers, at the Commanders’ Northwest Stadium when Trump was shown on the screens late in the first half – and again when the president was introduced by the stadium announcer at halftime. The Washington DC area has strong Democratic support, while Trump’s cuts to the government have affected many workers in the vicinity of the Commanders’ stadium. Sunday was not the first time Trump has received a hostile reception from a Washington sports crowd: he was greeted with ‘lock him up’ chants at the Washington Nationals’ home stadium during the 2019 World Series. Continue reading...
items.content: President greeted with jeers by many fans at gameTrump has appeared at several sports events this yearDonald Trump became the first sitting US president in nearly 50 years to attend a regular-season NFL game when he dropped in on the Detroit Lions’ win over the Washington Commanders on Sunday.There were boos from large sections of fans, as well as scattered cheers, at the Commanders’ Northwest Stadium when Trump was shown on the screens late in the first half – and again when the president was introduced by the stadium announcer at halftime. The Washington DC area has strong Democratic support, while Trump’s cuts to the government have affected many workers in the vicinity of the Commanders’ stadium. Sunday was not the first time Trump has received a hostile reception from a Washington sports crowd: he was greeted with ‘lock him up’ chants at the Washington Nationals’ home stadium during the 2019 World Series. Continue reading...

items.title: Growth in global demand for ‘green’ office buildings slows amid Trump policies
items.standfirst: Fall reported by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors as UN calls for accelerated action in buildings sector to meet global climate goals The growth in global demand for “green” office buildings has slowed after Donald Trump’s assault on environmental protection policies caused a slump in…
items.content: Fall reported by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors as UN calls for accelerated action in buildings sector to meet global climate goals The growth in global demand for “green” office buildings has slowed after Donald Trump’s assault on environmental protection policies caused a slump in…

items.title: Growth in global demand for ‘green’ office buildings slows amid Trump policies
items.standfirst: Fall reported by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors as UN calls for accelerated action in buildings sector to meet global climate goalsThe growth in global demand for “green” office buildings has slowed after Donald Trump’s assault on environmental protection policies caused a slump in interest in the US, according to a survey of construction industry professionals.Building occupiers and investors across North America and South America expressed significantly lower growth in demand for green commercial buildings, a shift that “seems to be in response to a change in US policy focus”, according to a survey of members of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). Reported demand across the rest of the world also fell, albeit not as sharply. Continue reading...
items.content: Fall reported by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors as UN calls for accelerated action in buildings sector to meet global climate goalsThe growth in global demand for “green” office buildings has slowed after Donald Trump’s assault on environmental protection policies caused a slump in interest in the US, according to a survey of construction industry professionals.Building occupiers and investors across North America and South America expressed significantly lower growth in demand for green commercial buildings, a shift that “seems to be in response to a change in US policy focus”, according to a survey of members of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). Reported demand across the rest of the world also fell, albeit not as sharply. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The growth in demand for green office buildings has slowed.
This is according to a survey of construction professionals.
The slowdown is linked to changes in US policy.
Demand fell in North and South America.
The UN is calling for accelerated action in the buildings sector.

items.title: Water levels below 3% in dam reservoirs for Iran’s second city, say reports
items.standfirst: Storage dwindles in Mashhad, home to 4 million people, as country struggles with droughtWater levels at the dam reservoirs supplying Iran’s north-eastern city of Mashhad have plunged below 3%, according to reports, as the country suffers from severe water shortages.“The water storage in Mashhad’s dams has now fallen to less than 3%,” Hossein Esmaeilian, the chief executive of the water company in Iran’s second largest city by population, told the ISNA news agency. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: UK to send defense equipment to help Belgium combat drone disruptions

items.title: Britain sends RAF specialists to help Belgium combat disruptive drones
items.standfirst: Incursions halted flights at Brussels and Liège airports last week with Russia said to be the most likely culpritBritain is deploying Royal Air Force specialists to help Belgium counter drone threats to the country’s airports after disruptive sightings last week that some politicians blamed on Russia.Sir Richard Knighton, the head of the UK’s armed forces, said the British military would provide “our people, our equipment” to help Belgium, though he was careful to say “we don’t yet know” the origin of the drones seen last week. Continue reading...
items.content: Incursions halted flights at Brussels and Liège airports last week with Russia said to be the most likely culpritBritain is deploying Royal Air Force specialists to help Belgium counter drone threats to the country’s airports after disruptive sightings last week that some politicians blamed on Russia.Sir Richard Knighton, the head of the UK’s armed forces, said the British military would provide “our people, our equipment” to help Belgium, though he was careful to say “we don’t yet know” the origin of the drones seen last week. Continue reading...

items.title: UK to send defence equipment to help Belgium combat drone disruptions
items.standfirst: The UK will send defence experts and equipment to Belgium to help it respond to drone sightings over military bases and airports, the head of the armed fores said on Sunday. Moscow has denied any connection to the incidents as European defence leaders have said the drones could be a form of Russian "hybrid warfare".
items.content: The UK will send defence experts and equipment to Belgium to help it respond to drone sightings over military bases and airports, the head of the armed fores said on Sunday. Moscow has denied any connection to the incidents as European defence leaders have said the drones could be a form of Russian "hybrid warfare".

ai_summary: The UK is sending RAF specialists to Belgium.
The assistance aims to counter drone threats to airports.
Disruptive drone sightings halted flights in Belgium.
Some officials suspect Russia's involvement in the incidents.
The UK will provide equipment and defense experts.
